Award.AwardTitle: SC Conference Experiencing HPC for Undergraduates Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this proposal is to fund travel for undergraduate students to participate in the Experiencing HPC for Undergraduates program at the SC13, SC14 and SC15 conferences. The primary goal of this program is to lead the students into research as an undergraduate and then encourage them to attend graduate school in HPC topics in Computer and Computational Science. The program makes use of several existing parts of the SC technical program, with additional activities specific to the program. The unique content for the participants in this program will include an HPC boot camp session, talks by well known researchers in the field, a panel featuring current graduate students, and a panel on academic and industry career opportunities in the HPC field.

The key idea of this program is that the best way to get people excited about HPC is to visit and participate in a major technical conference in the field. SC is an ideal venue for such a program since it combines elements of a high quality technical meeting (papers, posters, tutorials) with a major industry trade show (commercial and research exhibits, vendor briefings, birds of a feather sessions). By providing sophomore and junior undergraduates an opportunity to see what the field is about, it is believed that we can excite them about the field in time for them to apply to graduate school or decide on which industry to enter when they complete their bachelor?s degrees.

The goal of this program is to expand the High Performance Computing workforce by encouraging talented undergraduates to consider graduate studies and careers in the field of HPC. The program will make a special effort to recruit participants from under represented groups and minority serving institutions. HPC is critical to many national goals from scientific innovation to product development. Currently there is a shortage of new students entering the field. This program is designed to try to help meet those national needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main purpose of the project has been to enable undergraduate students to participate in the Experiencing HPC for Undergraduates program at the SC (formerly Supercomputing) conferences from 2013 to 2018. The primary goal of the program has been to lead the students into research as an undergraduate and then encourage them to attend graduate school in high performance computing (HPC) topics in Computer and Computational Science. The program made use of several existing parts of the SC technical program, with additional activities specific to the program. The unique content for the participants in this program included an HPC boot camp session, talks by well known researchers in the field, a panel featuring current graduate students, and a panel on academic and industry career opportunities in the HPC field.

The key idea of this program is that the best way to get people excited about HPC is to participate in a major technical conference in the field. Over the six years of the project, 125 undergraduate students were supported to attend the program and the conference, of which a significant fraction (between a third and half) of the students came from underrepresented groups in Computer and Computational Science.  In addition, the conference funded four or five international students every year to participate in the program, and those students came from every continent except Antarctica (using non-NSF funds).  By providing undergraduates with an opportunity to see the exciting science and technology in the HPC field, we have given them a reason to apply to graduate school or decide on which HPC-related industry to enter when they complete their undergraduate degrees.

The major goal of the program has been to expand the High Performance Computing workforce by encouraging talented undergraduates to consider graduate studies and careers in the field of HPC. The program made a special effort to recruit participants from underrepresented groups, minority serving institutions and primarily undergraduate institutions, and was very successful in that effort. HPC is critical to many national goals from scientific innovation to product development. There has been a shortage of new students entering the field, and the program was designed to help meet those national needs.  The program has been successful in its goals, with a significant percentage of participating students indicating through surveys that they will either enter graduate school or the workforce in HPC-related fields.
